results.headline: If You Can’t Stand the Analysis of Work and Parenthood, Get Out of the Kitchen

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of No Reservations

results.summary_short: “No Reservations” is a factory-sealed romantic comedy. But the emotional details of its characters’ journeys are surprising, honest and life-size.

results.headline: Alive and Well

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Punk's Not Dead

results.summary_short: Poor punk. Such a bundle of complexes, most of them encapsulated in the needlessly defensive title of Susan Dynner’s documentary “Punk’s Not Dead.”

results.headline: A Playwright in Prison, in Love and in Ruffles

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Moliere

results.summary_short: Jean-Baptiste Poquelin, better known as Molière, wrote more than 30 plays, every one of them a hundred times more witty and insightful than the movie “Molière.”

results.headline: A Life Derailed

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Laura Smiles

results.summary_short: Part domestic drama, part thriller, “Laura Smiles” is so ambitious that its ultimate failure is more depressing than anything in its dark script.

results.headline: A Draft-Board Break-In That Put Activism on Trial

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Camden 28

results.summary_short: Concise, inventive and unabashedly partisan, “The Camden 28” is a small movie that contains multitudes.

results.headline: Challenging a Rosy Yesterday by Confronting a Thorny Today

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Sugar Curtain

results.summary_short: “The Sugar Curtain” is a pensive valentine to literacy programs and childhood idealism left in the ashes of broken families and an economically bifurcated society.

results.headline: Showing the Unspeakable From Six Months Spent in Darfur

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Devil Came on Horseback

results.summary_short: Brutal, urgent, devastating — the documentary “The Devil Came on Horseback” demands to be seen as soon as possible and by as many viewers as possible.

results.headline: A Lesson in Global Warming From Two Cold, Cute Critters

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Arctic Tale

results.summary_short: Displaying more corn than is usually found at the North Pole, “Arctic Tale” documents the travails of a polar bear cub and a walrus pup as they struggle toward adulthood.

results.headline: On a Mission to Replace the Sun, Fighting Demons From Inner Space

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Sunshine

results.summary_short: The end may be nigh in “Sunshine” — the Sun is dying, as is, alas, poor Earth — but director Danny Boyle is having a grand old time.

results.headline: On the Road

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Walking to Werner

results.summary_short: The documentary “Walking to Werner” is a deeply self-reflexive work, perpetually at risk of disappearing into its own iris.

results.headline: Dude (Nyuck-Nyuck), I Love You (as If!)
results.display_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry

results.summary_short: “I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry” is sporadically funny, casually sexist, blithely racist and about as visually sophisticated as a parking-garage surveillance video.

results.headline: A Tribute to a Master Composer

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In Search of Mozart

results.summary_short: Setting the record straight literally and figuratively, “In Search of Mozart” is an adamantly linear, myth-busting stride through a prodigiously talented life.

results.headline: The Inquisition in Spain: Expected and Even Hailed

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Goya's Ghosts

results.summary_short: “Goya’s Ghosts,” the new feature from the director Milos Forman, is an unwieldy mix of political satire and lavish period soap opera.

results.headline: Adolescent Concepts of Beauty

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Cashback

results.summary_short: Beware films with protagonists depicted as vastly more sensitive than their fellow characters. The result may be a crock like “Cashback.”

results.headline: A Hijacked Bus and a Trio of Misfits

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Scrap Heaven

results.summary_short: In the writer and director Sang-il Lee’s “Scrap Heaven,” three strangers share a general dissatisfaction with life — and a fateful ride aboard a hijacked bus.

results.headline: A Care Package for Nostalgic Campers

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Summercamp!

results.summary_short: Nostalgic as only a project steered by two former campers can be, “Summercamp!” is a riot of talent shows and campfires, canoeing and holistic clowning.

results.headline: A Supermodel Captured, but Not by a Camera

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Captivity

results.summary_short: “Captivity” the movie has been thoroughly eclipsed by “Captivity” the marketing.

results.headline: They’re All Through With Love, Yet Searching for More

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Time

results.summary_short: Throughout “Time,” Kim Ki-duk flips between soapy melodrama and dry, self-aware comedy. The effect is thrilling and disorienting, like walking on a trampoline.

results.headline: Orphan Superpower in the Realm of Anime

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Tekkonkinkreet

results.summary_short: In the anime “Tekkonkinkreet,” two orphans of life’s storms sail through the air like birds, like superheroes, like Jackie Chan.

results.headline: Celebrity Journalism as Contact Sport

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Interview

results.summary_short: Vaporous and chilled to freezing, “Interview” lacks a single honest moment, but it does have plenty of diverting ones.
